title: Mississippi set to execute state's longest-serving death row inmate
summary: JACKSON, Miss. — Mississippi's longest-serving death row inmate is set to be executed Wednesday, nearly five decades after he kidnapped and killed a bank loan officer's wife in a violent ransom scheme
story: JACKSON, Miss. — Mississippi's longest-serving death row inmate is set to be executed Wednesday, nearly five decades after he kidnapped and killed a bank loan officer's wife in a violent ransom scheme.

Richard Gerald Jordan, a 79-year-old Vietnam veteran who suffers from post-traumatic stress disorder, is scheduled to receive a lethal injection at the Mississippi State Penitentiary in Parchman. He is one of several people on Mississippi's death row suing the state over its three-drug execution protocol, which they claim is inhumane.
Jordan would be the third person executed in the state in the last 10 years; the most recent execution was in December 2022.
His execution comes a day after a man was executed in Florida in what is shaping up to be a year with the most executions since 2015.

Jordan was sentenced to death in 1976 for killing and kidnapping Edwina Marter, a mother of two young children, earlier that year. As of the beginning of the year, Jordan is one of 22 people across the country sentenced for crimes in the 1970s who are still on death row, according to the Death Penalty Information Center.
Eric Marter, who was 11 when his mother was killed, said neither he, his brother, nor his father will attend the execution, but other family members will be there.
"It should have happened a long time ago," he said of the execution. "I'm not really interested in giving him the benefit of the doubt."

Mississippi Supreme Court records show that in January 1976, Jordan called the Gulf National Bank in Gulfport, Mississippi, and asked to speak with a loan officer. After he was told Charles Marter could speak to him, he hung up. He then looked up the Marters' home address in a telephone book and kidnapped Edwina Marter. According to court records, Jordan took her to a forest and shot her to death before calling her husband, claiming she was safe and demanding $25,000.
"He needs to be punished," Eric Marter said.

The execution ends Jordan's decades-long court process that included four trials and numerous appeals. On Monday, the U.S. Supreme Court rejected a petition that claimed he was denied due process rights.

"He was never given what, for a long time, the law has entitled him to, which is a mental health professional that is independent of the prosecution and can assist his defense," said lawyer Krissy Nobile, the director of Mississippi's Office of Capital Post-Conviction Counsel, who represents Jordan. "Because of that, his jury never got to hear about his Vietnam experiences."

A recent petition asking Mississippi Gov. Tate Reeves for clemency echoed Nobile's claim. It argues Jordan developed PTSD after serving three back-to-back tours in the Vietnam War, which could have been a factor in his crime.

"His war service, his war trauma, was considered not relevant in his murder trial," said Franklin Rosenblatt, the president of the National Institute of Military Justice, who wrote the petition on Jordan's behalf. "We just know so much more than we did 10 years ago, and certainly during Vietnam, about the effect of war trauma on the brain and how that affects ongoing behaviors."
Eric Marter said he doesn't buy that argument.
"I know what he did. He wanted money, and he couldn't take her with him. And he — so he did what he did," he said.

title: Eastern states swelter in record-breaking heat as 'extremely dangerous' conditions continue
summary: Almost 150 million people were under heat advisories and warnings Wednesday morning, as the extreme heatwave that has brought sweltering conditions.
story: Almost 150 million people were under heat advisories and warnings Wednesday morning, as the extreme heat wave that has brought sweltering conditions to the eastern half of the country and smashed dozens of temperature records showed no sign of ending.

The National Weather Service said the conditions remain "extremely dangerous" as the Ohio Valley is set to feel the heat through Friday, with more daily and monthly record temperatures expected to be broken.
Eastern heat persists

New York City, Baltimore, Philadelphia and Boston all hit 100 degrees Fahrenheit on Tuesday, as did parts of Maine. Dozens of heat records have been broken this week in the eastern half of the continental United States.
Tuesday was New York's hottest day since 2012, as voters lined up for the Democratic primary election. Wednesday will see another day in the upper-90s with overnight temperatures in the low-70s.
New York Gov. Kathy Hochul warned in a statement Tuesday that the electricity grid downstate was approaching "peak capacity" as people cranked up their air conditioners.

"It is critical to conserve electricity between now and 10:00 PM. That means setting window air conditioning units to 76 degrees and avoiding unnecessary appliance use," she said, while adding that it was still "critical" for people to stay safe in the dangerous heat.

The Washington Monument was shut for a second consecutive day Tuesday as both locals and tourists felt the heat, and Newark Liberty International Airport in New Jersey reached 103 degrees, the hottest it's been since 1966.

The heat has turned fatal, with authorities confirming that a woman in St. Ann, Missouri, died Monday of heat-related causes. Local Police Chief Aaron Jimenez said she died at home after having no water or air conditioning for at least three days.

Two 16-year-old hikers suffering from heat exhaustion had to be rescued from Gap Mountain in Jaffrey on Tuesday — one had to be carried down the mountain to a waiting ambulance, New Hampshire Fish and Game Conservation said on Facebook.
NBC Chicago reported that the heat was enough to buckle a section of road in Missouri, and three Chicago-area hospitals were struggling with their air conditioning, leading some patients to be moved.
Cumulative health risks

The weather service warned of the heat wave's cumulative health effects and stressed the importance of drinking enough water and finding somewhere cool, especially for vulnerable groups, such as the elderly and those with pre-existing health conditions.

"This is after several consecutive days of oppressive heat, which should exacerbate heat-related health impacts. This level of heat is dangerous to anyone without effective cooling and/or adequate hydration," the service said.

"You get the combination of the extreme heat and humidity but no relief," Jacob Asherman, a meteorologist at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s Weather Prediction Center, told The Associated Press. "It’s kind of been just everything stacked on top of itself ... It just speaks to how strong this heat wave is. This is a pretty, pretty extreme event."
Elsewhere, scattered thunderstorms will hit the Southwest on Wednesday, with possible flash flooding in parts of New Mexico and Texas.
Cooler weather on the way
The heat should ease as the week goes on. A new cold weather front is moving through the mid-Atlantic, bringing highs closer to 90 and, for some areas, the 80s or even 70s.

"There's even a rare backdoor cool front that will drop southward from New England to part of the mid-Atlantic region during the middle and latter part of this week," AccuWeather Senior Meteorologist Brett Anderson said. "This can dramatically drop temperatures by 20-40 degrees in some cases, which is about as big as it gets this time of the year."

title: Mariska Hargitay on the Stunning Moment She Learned About Biological Dad: 'Jolt Went Through My Body'
summary: Mariska Hargitay recalled learning that her biological father was Nelson Sardelli from a Jayne Mansfield fan on Alex Cooper's "Call Her Daddy" podcast.
story: Mariska Hargitay was 25 years old when she learned the stunning truth about her biological father from a man she had never met.

The "Law & Order: SVU" star spoke with Alex Cooper on the June 25 episode of Cooper's "Call Her Daddy" podcast about how she found out her biological father is Italian singer Nelson Sardelli, not Hungarian bodybuilder and actor Mickey Hargitay.

Hargitay had journeyed to the home of Sabin Gray, a diehard fan of her late mother, actor and 1950s sex symbol Jayne Mansfield, to see his collection of Mansfield memorabilia. Hargitay, whose  HBO documentary, "My Mom Jayne," comes out on June 27, ended the visit with a shocking realization.

"It was a little overwhelming for me because there were life-size cutouts, and it was truly like a museum or a shrine to her," Hargitay said. "That was hard for me at that age to sort of understand. ... I’m seeing all this stuff that I had never seen and kind of grew up away from all of that."

"He’s showing me all these photos. He’s showing me whatever it is, dresses that she had that he’d collected, earrings that she wore, things from movies from the movie set, props or whatever, and then he says to me, 'Do you want to see a picture of Nelson?'" she recalled.
The question immediately unnerved Hargitay, who was 3 years old when her mother died in a car accident in 1967.
"I just looked at him, and this jolt went through my body, and I said, 'Who's Nelson?'" she said. "And then I knew in one second."
Hargitay remembered the blood draining out of Gray's face after asking her about Sardelli.

"He sort of panicked and turned white, and he said, 'Oh, it’s probably not true, it’s probably not true,' and that’s when I knew," Hargitay said. "And I think that (Gray) couldn’t believe that I didn’t know. I was 25, how could I not know?"
Hargitay was then shown a picture of Sardelli.
"On a cellular level, it was just like DNA talking to DNA," she said. "I knew it was true, and I just really thought my life was over."
Hargitay was distraught as she departed Gray's home.

"I remember leaving and driving to my brother’s house, and I thought I was going to crash my car because I was so not present," she said. "I was totally dissociated and out of my body, and I got to my brother’s house. I didn’t even know how I got there, but I knew that I shouldn’t be driving. It was crazy."

Hargitay's world was upended. She was very close with Mickey Hargitay, who had raised her after Mansfield was killed in an accident in which Mariska and her two brothers, Zoltan and Mickey Jr., were also in the car.

"The one thing I did have, the one thing that I was rooted in, the one thing that was my constant, was no longer mine," she said about realizing Mickey Hargitay was not her biological father. "And my identity was just smashed. It was like it broke in two."
She struggled to deal with a "thousand pellets of hard truth."
"(I'm) going, 'My brothers aren’t my brothers, I’m not Hungarian, I'm not related to all my family that I grew up with in Hungary,'" she said.
It started to make sense to her why during her childhood "everyone asked me if I was Italian."
Once she drove to the home of one of her brothers, she asked him if he knew about Sardelli being her biological father.

"I’m very, very, very, very close with my brother, and he didn’t (know), so then that was also confusing," she said. "And then I went up to my dad’s house, and I was hysterically crying and in a state."
She said Mickey Hargitay was in the process of physically building her a home when she asked him about Sardelli.
"So I drive up to the house that he is building me and confront him, and he was like, 'What? What are you talking about? Are you crazy? That’s so not true,'" she said.

"He kept saying, 'You look like my father, you look exactly like my father, you're a Hargitay to the end,'" she continued. "The irony is that I'm more like my dad than anyone in our whole family. Like, I am mini-Mickey, right? And so it was just a very extraordinarily painful moment. I say that this is the moment that I became an adult, and it's so visceral for me because I was in so much pain, I was so overwhelmed."
Despite finding out the stunning truth about her bloodline, she did not press Mickey Hargitay on the issue.

"I was so overwhelmed and I was in the 'me, me, me, me, oh, my gosh, my life is over,' and then looking at this man who’s been nothing but loving to me and nothing but this amazing father to me, and I saw his pain," she said. "And I said, 'It doesn’t matter what I feel. I love him. We're done here.'

"And so I said, 'OK, thank you for telling me,' and I pretended that I believed him, and we never spoke of it again," she continued. "And then he used to say, even before he died, 'Remember when you thought that crazy thing?' And I go, 'I know, wasn't that nuts?'"
Hargitay told Cooper she’ll “never know” the extent of Mickey’s knowledge on the matter.
“I think that he integrated it in, ‘This is my new reality,’” she said. “He made a choice and that was his new truth. And whether it’s true or not emotionally, it was his truth.”
While she was managing her emotions with Mickey, Hargitay also was reeling at the thought that Sardelli had not acknowledged her as his daughter.

"That was where the injury was," she said, "is, why wasn’t I claimed? He must have known. He didn’t care, he didn’t love me, I wasn’t worth it, I was nothing to him. He knew, he had to know that I was his daughter, and I wasn’t worth it. I wasn’t valuable enough, and that’s what I lived with, is that I wasn’t enough."
"So having that feeling of, my mother left me and then again my father abandoned me was so hard to integrate or make sense out of," she added.
At 61 years old, Hargitay said she now has the benefit of being able to view the situation with more wisdom.

"I'm so grateful for this life to grow into the miracle of my story, and having this comprehensive understanding and getting the full perspective and now seeing that I had such a limited, teeny, teeny, teeny sliver of the truth (at the time)," she said.

title: 'The Ultimatum: Queer Love' Season 2 Cast: Meet All 6 Couples
summary: "The Ultimatum: Queer Love" has six new couples. Here is the cast, who gave the ultimatum and how to follow them all on Instagram.
story: "The Ultimatum: Queer Love" is back for Season 2, featuring six new couples deciding the future of their relationship.

In the show, couples at a crossroads embark on an experiment to decide if they want to get married. One person is ready to take the plunge. The other has reservations about marriage for a myriad of reasons. And so, an ultimatum is issued.

During the eight-week process, each couple breaks up and re-couples with new people. At the end of the season, they will decide whether they will say “I do” to an engagement with their original spouse or walk away to explore another connection. Juicy, right?

In Season 2 hosted by “Sweet Magnolia’s” JoAnna Garcia Swisher, six queer couples arrive on the scene to embark on the journey. And if the trailer is any indication, this season is sure to be a wild ride.
“My worst fear is that I would get to a point that I was ready, and you were falling in love with someone else,” Pilar Dizon says through tears. “Now it’s happening.”
In another scene, a different cast member says over B-roll, “It’s definitely possible to fall in love with two different people.” Another unidentified cast member reveals her frustration.
“How can you be in love with somebody else,” she says. “My heart is shattered.”
Keep reading to find out more about this season’s couples, using information from Netflix's press site Tudum.
AJ Blount and Britney Thompson
Who gave the ultimatum? Britney
AJ, 28, and Britney, 27, who both use she/her pronouns, first met at a night club in Los Angeles five years ago, and the two have been together ever since.
Britney, a registered nurse and entrepreneur, gave AJ the ultimatum after she claimed she didn’t want to get married due to fear she’d always come second to Britney’s career.
Follow them on Instagram: @ajalways_jammin and @britneythmpsn
Haley Drexler and Pilar Dizon
Who gave the ultimatum? Haley

Haley and Pilar, both 29, met when they were both orientation leaders during their freshmen year of college. The couple, who use she/her pronouns, have been together for 10 years. But Haley is ready to take the next step.
Follow them on Instagram: @haleydrexler and @dr.dmusic
Kyle Neal and Bridget Matloff
Who gave the ultimatum? Kyle

Kyle, 30, and Bridget, 28, who both use she/they pronouns, first met after swiping right on a dating app. Two and a half years later, Kyle is certain that their modern love story should be sealed with a ring.
Follow them on Instagram: @inkybinky231 and @bridgetmatloff
Mel Vitale and Marie Robertson
Who gave the ultimatum? Marie

Mel and Marie, both 27, have been dating for four years. The pair, who both use she/her pronouns, not only have love for each other, but their shared food truck business. But for Marie, only marriage symbolizes that the two are driving in the right direction.
Follow them on Instagram: @inkybinky231 and @bridgetmatloff
Dayna Mathews and Magen Mourad
Who gave the ultimatum? Dayna

Dayna, 25, and Magan, 27, who both use she/her pronouns, may have been together for the least amount of time compared to the other couples, but make no mistake. After a year and a half with Magan, Dayna knows what she wants, and it’s to tie the knot.
Follow them on Instagram: @mdayna and @maganmourad
Ashley Johnson and Marita Prodger
Who gave the ultimatum? Ashley

Sparks first flew when Ashley, 30, and Marita, 25, matched on a dating app. Three years later, the couple, who both use she/her pronouns, have had their ups and downs in terms of each partner feeling fully chosen. But Ashley is ready for the ultimate commitment.
Follow them on Instagram: @ashleyj_19 and @maritaprodger

title: Is Tom Sandoval Moving to the Next Round on 'AGT'?
summary: Tom Sandoval auditioned on "America's Got Talent,— but is he advancing to the next round of the competition?
story: Tom Sandoval auditioned on "America's Got Talent,— but is he advancing to the next round of the competition?

Sandoval and his band, Tom Sandoval & The Most Extras, performed a cover of a-ha’s 1985 hit “Take On Me” in front of judges Simon Cowell, Sofía Vergara, Howie Mandel and Mel B in an episode that aired on June 24.
The group received a standing ovation from the crowd, as well as all four judges.

"You made me smile! You gave me happy vibes," Mel B said. "And apart from that song being one of my favorite songs, you all looked like you were fully enjoying yourselves, and you're not embarrassed to say that you are a cover band."
The former Spice Girls member added that she may need a cover band at her upcoming wedding.
Vergara and Mandel also shared words of support on how much they loved the performance. However, Cowell started his feedback with some brutal honesty.
"For me, the vocals weren't great, Tom, I'm going to be honest with you," Cowell said, leading to boos from the audience.
Sandoval bit his lip and looked down as Cowell continued.
"However, not everyone comes on this show to get a record deal. Sometimes it's about being true to who you are."
The judges then began to vote, with Mel B and Vergara giving Sandoval immediate yeses, and the crowd chanting, "Yes!" as Cowell deliberated.
"I'm going to say... yes!" Cowell said, meaning Tom Sandoval & The Most Extras will be headed to the next round of the NBC competition.
Sandoval and his band jumped up and down and celebrated, before Sandoval thanked the judges and headed off stage.
He then told "AGT" host Terry Crews how much the moment meant to him.
"It means so much to me, to see all these people coming from different places, that come together and were happy and cheering for us, and rooting for us!" he said.
Sandoval also posted photos from his audition on Instagram.

"I feel so honored to be able to bring my band into to such a cool and different experience," he wrote in the caption. "I’m also thankful for the ones who came to support me and of course, all of my fans supporting us! Love y’all!! 🤘🏼🎸🖤 But the big question is.. do you think we made it to the next round?"
(NBC is owned by TODAY.com's parent company, NBCUniversal.)

title: Taylor Swift Delivers Surprise Performance at Travis Kelce's Event
summary: Taylor Swift gave a surprise performance at Travis Kelce's Tight Ends & Friends concert in Nashville and also made what fans are deeming her red carpet debut with the athlete.
story: Taylor Swift supported Travis Kelce in the sweetest way.
On June 24, Swift gave a surprise performance at her boyfriend's Tight Ends & Friends concert at the Brooklyn Bowl Nashville.
While she was on stage, fans took videos of her playing her guitar and singing her hit song "Shake It Off." For the performance, Swift donned a black mini dress and a pair of matching boots.
When she was done, the singer received a loud applause from fans and thanked her band before walking off the stage.

The annual event is hosted by Kelce's organization, Tight End University. In 2021, he founded TEU with fellow athletes George and Greg Olsen, and the organization aims to bring tight ends together for a bonding experience.

In addition to the concert, Swift also attended the event's opening night with Kelce. In a video shared on TEU's Instagram, the "Midnights" singer could be seen walking into the event with Kelce by her side.
The pair held hands and Swift shot a smile at Kelce, who was wearing a white knit polo shirt and a pair of matching shorts. Swift wore a bit of color while sporting a green gingham, two-piece set.
Online, fans were gushing about the moment, with many calling it the couple's first known red carpet event they attended together.
"The red carpet moment that the world has waited on for two years happened at TEU? I kind of love this. Met Gala? Grammys? Hell no we’re doing TEU! 👏👏," one person commented on the post.
Another said, "This, as their first red carpet appearance, is kinda perfect!!😄."

Swift's TEU performance comes just a few weeks after she revealed that she now owns her master recordings. In a letter to fans posted on her website, she said, “All of the music I’ve ever made... now belongs... to me.”

title: Mariska Hargitay Reveals When She Believes Benson and Stabler Should Get Together
summary: Mariska Hargitay talks on "Call Her Daddy" about when she thinks Benson and Stabler (Chris Meloni) should get together romantically on "Law & Order: SVU."
story: One-half of one of television’s most beloved will they/won’t they pairings has weighed in on when she believes the characters should elevate their partnership to a romance.
Mariska Hargitay appeared on the “Call Her Daddy” podcast June 25 and offered an honest response when asked by host Alex Cooper if Olivia Benson and Elliot Stabler will ever get together.
“Maybe on the last episode,” Hargitay responded with a smile. “I think that’s when they should be together.”

Benson and Stabler, portrayed by Chris Meloni, have been in each other’s lives for over 25 years. The same can be said of Hargitay and Meloni, who have been close friends since “Law & Order: SVU” began in 1999.
Cooper asked if Hargitay wants the characters to be together when the end comes. The Emmy winner responded, “If it’s right.”
“We’ll see when we get there,” she added.
“SVU” is heading into its 27th season. Meloni left after the 12th season in 2011 after failed contract negotiations, which is another topic Hargitay discussed on the podcast.
“I was devastated,” she said, noting that his “surprising” exit happened “very quickly.”
“I tried everything I could to fix it and change it,” she said.

Meloni brought back his character in April 2021 to lead his own spinoff, “Law & Order: Organized Crime,” which just concluded its fifth season on Peacock after four seasons on NBC, the home of “SVU.” Benson and Stabler have shared multiple scenes in crossover episodes of both shows since Meloni’s return. He most recently had a guest appearance on “SVU” in April.
Hargitay said Benson and Stabler are “soulmates, in a way.”
“Chris has had a profound impact on my life, my artistry,” she said. “I think we’ve had a big impact on each other. And so, Olivia and Elliot are, but let’s see where the story takes us, you know?”
Hargitay also said she and Meloni are “connected” and “so close.”

“It’s like we’ve been through the battle together,” she added. “We know each other so well. We love each other so much. We respect each other so much. We connected, obviously, by living these stories and going so deep together for so many years acting, and he and I really bond over comedy. We have a very similar sense of humor.”
She also explained the two have a shared perspective and shorthand with each other, echoing comments she told TODAY.com about their bond last year.
“I trust his choices because he’s incapable of not telling the truth — as a person and an actor,” she said at the time while laughing.
Hargitay told Cooper she and Meloni are “so comfortable with each other.”
“We deeply trust each other. Whatever he needs, I will always be there for him, and that’s mutual.”
Their mutual respect was on display at the Tribeca Festival premiere of Hargitay’s documentary about her mother, “My Mom Jayne,” earlier this month.

Meloni attended with his wife, Sherman, and their daughter, Sophia. He recently posted photos to Instagram from the event, including one with his wife, daughter and two of Hargitay’s kids, whom she shares with husband Peter Hermann.
“Busy summer so far with celebration, friends, tv mom, ppl I love making films,” he wrote in part June 24.
Hargitay popped into the comments section of the post with three heart emoji.

title: Scarlett Johansson Explains Kissing Jonathan Bailey Twice on Red Carpet: ‘I’ve Got a Lot of Love To Give’
summary: Scarlett Johansson weighed in on TODAY about fan reactions to the kisses she shared with her “Jurassic World Rebirth” co-star Jonathan Bailey on red carpets.
story: Scarlett Johansson is the type of person to kiss and tell.

The Oscar-nominated actor weighed in on fan reactions to the kisses she shared with her “Jurassic World Rebirth” co-star Jonathan Bailey on red carpets. The first was at the movie’s world premiere in London on June 17 and another happened at the New York premiere on June 23.
While appearing on TODAY June 25, Johansson agreed with Craig Melvin’s assessment that Bailey is “just so attractive.”
“Yeah, you said it,” Johansson said.
“He’s a lovable guy. What can I say?” she continued. “I don’t know. We’re just friendly people.”
Johansson also said she rolls with the punches when it comes to the buzz the smooches have caused.
“Nothing surprises me, you know what I mean?” she said about the public reactions. “Nothing surprises me these days. But, yeah, I’ve got a lot of love to give, what can I say?”
As for Bailey, he shares the same sentiment.
“Life is too short not to be able to express your love for your friends,” Bailey said while appearing with “Jurassic World Rebirth” co-star Mahershala Ali on TODAY with Jenna & Friends on June 24.
Fans of Johansson and Bailey were praising them for showing love for each other.
“Normalize a little smooch with your best friends,” one person commented on TODAY’s Instagram video of their smooch in London.
“I think this is an accurate and appropriate thing for friendships!” someone else commented.
“I’m so glad when two awesome celebrities become good friends after making a movie,” another person gushed.
Moviegoers can see Johansson and Bailey in “Jurassic World Rebirth” when it opens July 2.

title: Bobby Sherman, Teen Idol in the 1960s and '70s, Dies at 81
summary: Bobby Sherman, whose smile and shaggy mop helped make him into a teen idol in the 1960s and '70s with bubblegum pop hits like "Little Woman" and "Julie, Do Ya Love Me," has died.
story: Bobby Sherman, whose winsome smile and fashionable shaggy mop top helped make him into a teen idol in the 1960s and '70s with bubblegum pop hits like "Little Woman" and "Julie, Do Ya Love Me," has died. He was 81.

His wife, Brigitte Poublon, announced the death Tuesday and family friend John Stamos posted her message on Instagram: "Bobby left this world holding my hand — just as he held up our life with love, courage, and unwavering grace." Sherman revealed he had Stage 4 cancer earlier this year.

Sherman was a squeaky-clean regular on the covers of Tiger Beat and Sixteen magazines, often with hair over his eyes and a choker on his neck. His face was printed on lunchboxes, cereal boxes and posters that hung on the bedroom walls of his adoring fans. He landed at No. 8 in TV Guide's list of "TV's 25 Greatest Teen Idols."

He was part of a lineage of teen heartthrobs who emerged as mass-market, youth-oriented magazines and TV took off, connecting fresh-scrubbed Ricky Nelson in the 1950s to David Cassidy in the '60s, all the way to Justin Bieber in the 2000s.

Sherman had four Top 10 hits on the Billboard Hot 100 chart — "Little Woman," "Julie, Do Ya Love Me," "Easy Come, Easy Go," and "La La La (If I Had You)." He had six albums on the Billboard 200 chart, including "Here Comes Bobby," which spent 48 weeks on the album chart, peaking at No. 10. His career got its jump start when he was cast in the ABC rock 'n' roll show "Shindig!" in the mid-'60s. Later, he starred in two television series — "Here Come the Brides" (1968-70) and "Getting Together" (1971).

After the limelight moved on, Sherman became a certified medical emergency technician and instructor for the Los Angeles Police Department, teaching police recruits first aid and CPR. He donated his salary.

"A lot of times, people say, 'Well, if you could go back and change things, what would you do?'" he told The Tulsa World in 1997. "And I don't think I'd change a thing — except to maybe be a little bit more aware of it, because I probably could've relished the fun of it a little more. It was a lot of work. It was a lot of blood, sweat and tears. But it was the best of times."
A life-changing Hollywood party
Sherman, with sky blue eyes and dimples, grew up in the San Fernando Valley, singing Ricky Nelson songs and performing with a high-school rock band.

"I was brought up in a fairly strict family," he told the Sunday News newspaper in Lancaster, Pennsylvania, in 1998. "Law and order were important. Respect your fellow neighbor, remember other people's feelings. I was the kind of boy who didn't do things just to be mischievous."

He was studying child psychology at a community college in 1964 when his girlfriend took him to a Hollywood party, which would change his life. He stepped onstage and sang with the band. Afterward, guests Jane Fonda, Natalie Wood and Sal Mineo asked him who his agent was. They took his number and, a few days later, an agent called him and set him up with "Shindig!"

Sherman hit true teen idol status in 1968, when he appeared in "Here Come the Brides," a comedy-adventure set in boom town Seattle in the 1870s. He sang the show's theme song, "Seattle," and starred as young logger Jeremy Bolt, often at loggerheads with brother, played by David Soul. It lasted two seasons.

Following the series, Sherman starred in "Getting Together," a spinoff of "The Partridge Family," about a songwriter struggling to make it in the music business. He became the first performer to star in three TV series before the age of 30. That television exposure soon translated into a fruitful recording career: His first single, "Little Woman," earned a gold record in 1969.

"While the rest of the world seemed jumbled up and threatening, Sherman's smiling visage beamed from the bedroom walls of hundreds of thousands of teen-age girls, a reassuring totem against the riots, drugs, war protests and free love that raged outside," The Tulsa World said in 1997.
His movies included "Wild In Streets," "He is My Brother" and "Get Crazy."
From music to medicine

Sherman pulled back from his celebrity career after several years of a frantic schedule, telling The Washington Post: "I'd film five days a week, get on a plane on a Friday night and go someplace for matinee and evening shows Saturday and Sunday, then get on a plane and go back to the studio to start filming again. It was so hectic for three years that I didn't know what home was."

Sherman's pivot to becoming an emergency medical technician in 1988 was born out of a longtime fascination with medicine. Sherman said that affinity blossomed when he raised his sons with his first wife, Patti Carnel. They would get scrapes and bloody noses and he became the family's first-aid provider. So he started learning basic first aid and cardiopulmonary resuscitation from the Red Cross.

"If I see an accident, I feel compelled to stop and give aid even if I'm in my own car," he told the St. Petersburg Times. "I carry equipment with me. And there's not a better feeling than the one you get from helping somebody out. I would recommend it to everybody."

In addition to his work with the Los Angeles Police Department, he was a reserve deputy with the San Bernardino County Sheriff's Department, working security at the courthouse. Sherman estimated that, as a paramedic, he helped five women deliver babies in the backseats of cars or other impromptu locations.

In one case, he helped deliver a baby on the sidewalk and, after the birth, the new mother asked Sherman's partner what his name was. "When he told her Bobby, she named the baby Roberta. I was glad he didn't tell her my name was Sherman," he told the St. Petersburg Times in 1997.
The teen idols grow up
He was named LAPD's Reserve Officer of the Year for 1999 and received the FBI's Exceptional Service Award and the "Twice a Citizen" Award by the Los Angeles County Reserve Foundation.

In a speech on the floor of the U.S. House of Representatives in 2004, then-Rep. Howard McKeon wrote: "Bobby is a stellar example of the statement 'to protect and serve.' We can only say a simple and heartfelt thank you to Bobby Sherman and to all the men and women who courageously protect and serve the citizens of America."
Later, Sherman would join the 1990s-era "Teen Idols Tour" with former 1960s heartthrobs Micky Dolenz and Davy Jones of the Monkees and Peter Noone of Herman's Hermits.

The Chicago Sun-Times in 1998 described one of Sherman's performances: "Dressed to kill in black leather pants and white shirt, he was showered with roses and teddy bears as he started things off with 'Easy Come, Easy Go.' As he signed scores of autographs at the foot of the stage, it was quickly draped by female fans of every conceivable age group."
Sherman also co-founded the Brigitte and Bobby Sherman Children's Foundation in Ghana, which provides education, health, and welfare programs to children in need.
He is survived by two sons, Christopher and Tyler, and his wife.
"Even in his final days, he stayed strong for me. That's who Bobby was — brave, gentle, and full of light," Poublon wrote.

title: Who Goes Home on ‘Love Island USA’? Tonight Ends With 2 Dramatic Dumpings — and a Surprise
summary: Who is dumped from "Love Island USA" tonight in Season 7, Episode 20. A re-coupling leaves two people dumped from the island — but not without a surprise twist.
story: Spoilers ahead for "Love Island USA" Season 7, Episode 20.

Over on “Love Island USA,” Casa Amor week has kicked off. The girl islanders have vacated the villa to head over to the nearby house, where six guy bombshells awaited them. The boy islanders were left behind — but not without a group of five girl bombshells to keep them company.

We learned in the episode prior the stakes of the first night: All the islanders have entered Casa week single and had to couple up with the new bombshells. This ends up being a game of numbers, though, and TJ at the villa and Amaya at Casa are left without matches. They learn that they have to find a connection within 24 hours or else they’re dumped from the show.
Episode 20 ends with a re-coupling between the islanders and the bombshells — and a dramatic exit of two people. Here’s what happens.
More of ‘Love Island USA’
Meet the Casa Amor Bombshells for ‘Love Island USA’ Season 7‘Love Island USA’ Season 7 Cast: Who’s Still in the Villa?‘Love Island USA’ Puts a Twist on Casa Amor: New Rules, Explained
Meet the Casa Amor Bombshells for ‘Love Island USA’ Season 7
‘Love Island USA’ Season 7 Cast: Who’s Still in the Villa?
‘Love Island USA’ Puts a Twist on Casa Amor: New Rules, Explained
What Happens in ‘Love Island USA’ Season 7, Episode 20?

Episode 20 picks up where all that left off. Everyone at the villa and everyone at Casa are coupled up with bombshells and seeing what comes of those connections. Meanwhile, Amaya and TJ currently don’t have couples — and if they don’t find one within the next day, they’re dumped from the island.

Over at Casa, Cierra, who has a strong connection with Nic back at the villa, is vibing with bombshell Elan. “Within five minutes of conversing, I was like, ‘Oh, s—, this is going really well,” she says in a confessional. Later, she gets emotional about leaning into a new connection after developing such strong feelings for Nic.

Things seem to be going well for the other girl islanders: Chelley vibes with bombshell Chris. Iris likes bombshell Zac. And Huda is seeking out bombshell J.D. Huda reflects in a confessional how much she’s enjoying herself after dedicating so much of her time prior to Jeremiah, who was dumped before Casa.
“It’s so nice to finally be in the zone,” she says in a confessional. “I feel like I’ve been so closed off, and I haven’t gotten a chance to form connections. I’m having so much fun.”
At the villa, bombshells Coco and Clarke are both connecting with Taylor and Ace, and bombshell Jaden is liking both Austin and Nic.

The stakes remain high for Amaya and TJ, who have to find a connection by nighttime. Amaya has an emotional talk with J.D., then has another chat with Zak, who kisses her for a second time. TJ is continuing to chat with most of the girl bombshells in the villa and seems to connect most with Vanna.

Just as Olandria, Cierra and Huda wonder what happens to the singled-out islander if Amaya finds a connection, both groups at Casa and the villa receive a text: A re-coupling is taking place that night, and those without a pair will be single and vulnerable.
Who Goes Home on ‘Love Island USA’ Tonight?
When the groups at both Casa and the villa are invited to gather around the fire pits for the re-couplings, the two singles — Amaya and TJ — are told to stand.

Viewers see what happens at Casa first. If a bombshell wishes to couple with Amaya, they’re asked to stand. Zak gets to his feet. He coupled with Olandria when they first got to Casa — so this now leaves Olandria vulnerable.

The rest of the bombshells are asked if any of them wish to couple with Olandria. When nobody stands, the group gets a text that Olandria is dumped from the island. The girls are understandably emotional, as Olandria is an original cast member and had a strong connection with Taylor, who’s back at the villa.
“I did not want to say goodbye here, and I feel like this time I was actually getting it right,” Olandria says in her confessional as she leaves Casa.
Viewers then get to see the re-coupling at the villa. The same gist plays out — but this time with a lot more shuffling.

It starts with TJ. If any of the girls wish to couple with TJ, they’re asked to stand — so Vanna does. Vanna had been coupled with Ace since the girl bombshells arrived at the villa, so the process begins again: If anyone wants to couple with Ace, they’re asked to stand. Coco then gets up, leaving her current match, Taylor, vulnerable. Then Clarke stands for Taylor, leaving Nic single.
When nobody stands to couple with Nic, the villa’s re-coupling ends there: Nic is asked to pack his bags.
Nic and Olandria Are Dumped ... or Are They?!
Just as viewers are watching Nic grab his suitcase and leave the villa, a last-minute shocker wraps up the episode.
A black SUV is awaiting him outside — and it’s Olandria in the backseat, shouting at him to get in. Where is this getaway car heading to? “Love Island USA” will leave that for next time.

title: Man Goes Viral For Carnival Cruise Karaoke Performance
summary: While aboard a Carnival Cruise, Tyler Heyworth surprised the crowd with a lively rendition of Keith Sweat's 1996 hit, “Nobody.”
story: One Carnival Cruise has a new singing celebrity on board: College student Tyler Heyworth, whose charm and vocal chops left shocked boat passengers on their feet.

While aboard a Carnival Cruise en route to Cozumel, Mexico, Heyworth found himself on stage at a karaoke event in front of a small crowd of strangers. Microphone in hand, the Georgia native surprised the crowd with a lively rendition of Keith Sweat's 1996 hit, “Nobody.”

As Heyworth kicked off the ballad, one viral TikTok video captured dozens of cruise guests erupting with laughter and applause. The supportive crowd sang along with Heyworth throughout the entire song and gave the performance a standing ovation once the chorus came to a close.
Several onlookers were quick to post the karaoke performance on TikTok, where the video quickly amassed over one million views.
In an interview with TODAY.com, Heyworth reveals that his penchant for ‘90s karaoke occurs only on cruises.

“You may think I look pretty confident up there, but normally I wouldn't do that around where I live because I’m too nervous,” Heyworth says. “On cruises, the way I think about it is like, ‘Oh, I’m never going to see these people again. Why don’t I have a little fun?’”
Fans of Heyworth's song choice made their opinions clear in person and in the comment section.
“I want to book a Carnival Cruise, but only if Tyler is there singing this song,” one commenter wrote on the video.
“If tyler ain’t on the cruise I ain’t goin,” another user said.

Heyworth admits that a trial run performance occurred the night before, where he sang to a small group of vacationers. The following evening, Heyworth's dad gave him the confidence he needed to croon to a larger crowd.

“My dad looked at me and said, ‘there’s a bigger crowd out here tonight. I’ll give you 10 bucks if you do the same song again,’” Heyworth recalls. Ultimately, the money was the motivation, and the resulting video is now viral TikTok gold.
“I’m on my 8th Tyler video POV,” one TikTok user wrote with a laughing emoji.
“At this point we know everyone who was on The Tyler Carnival Cruise Tour,” wrote another user.
Along with “Nobody,” Heyworth was also seen belting out Usher's “Nice & Slow” and “Let Me Love You” by Mario, complete with a cameo from his brother Timmy.
Heyworth notes that while his go-to genre is ‘90s R&B, he doesn’t have a tried-and-true karaoke tune.
“‘Nobody’ isn't my go-to song, but it was a song I had really enjoyed one summer,” he says. “I saw it on the set list, and I was like, ‘You know what, why not?’”
Even Carnival Cruise decided to join in on the fun with their own TikTok of “The Tyler Show,” with the words “SOLD OUT” written underneath.
Despite not having any future cruise performances lined up, Heyworth plans to continue singing when he can, especially in the car.
“I’m definitely gonna keep doing karaoke,” he says.
As for that $10 bet? Heyworth's dad made good on his promise.

title: Aaron Rodgers Defends Wife’s Privacy: ‘She Deserves the Right to That’
summary: Aaron Rodgers is explaining why he has not publicly revealed his wife’s identity after confirming earlier this month that he is now a happily married man.
story: Aaron Rodgers is explaining why he has not publicly revealed his wife’s identity after confirming he is now a married man.

The 41-year-old NFL player appeared on “The Pat McAfee Show” June 24 and spoke about entering a new chapter in his life as he recently signed with the Pittsburgh Steelers. Toward the end of the conversation, he also briefly touched on another major change regarding his personal life: getting married. During the interview, he repeatedly stressed why he prioritizes maintaining his wife’s privacy.

When McAfee joked about being invited to a possible wedding reception for the couple, Rodgers firmly shut down the idea. He replied, “It’s a sick society, isn’t it? I’ve lived in the public eye for 20 years. I had a public relationship. How did that work out?”
Without clarifying which relationship he was referring to, he mentioned that in the past, information about his address was leaked and he also had to deal with attention from paparazzi.
“I didn’t like any of that and now I’m with somebody who’s private, who doesn’t want to be in the public eye,” he continued. “(She) didn’t sign up to be a celebrity, doesn’t want to be a part of it.”

The quarterback said that his attempt to retreat from life in the public eye over the last few years has caused him to be labeled as “weird.” He also claimed that paparazzi have been following him recently to snap a picture of his wife.
“What is the entitlement to information that we’re living in society these days where that’s, like, a norm?” he asked.
He noted that it is a security issue before speaking more about his bride.
Rodgers shared, “My wife is a private person, doesn’t have social media, hasn’t been a public person, doesn’t want to be a public person.”
The athlete revealed that he intends to also completely withdraw from the spotlight when his professional football career ends.
“I know that I’ve chosen to be in the public eye for one more season, but my private life is staying private,” he said.

Rodgers then reiterated his point, adding, “My private life is my private life, and it’s going to stay that way. I’m with somebody who wants to be private, and if and when she wants to be out and there’s a picture, she’ll choose that. She deserves the right to that.”
He announced earlier this month that he had tied the knot earlier this month in a press conference following his first practice with the Pittsburgh Steelers.
When one journalist mentioned that it looked like he was possibly wearing a wedding ring, he confirmed she was correct.
“Yeah, it’s a wedding ring,” he casually responded June 10.
Another reporter asked how long ago he said “I do.” Rodgers replied, “It’s been a couple of months,” without providing more details about his wife or their nuptials.

title: 'Pioneer Woman' Ree Drummond Announces New Series
summary: Ree Drummond, the "Pioneer Woman," is launching a new YouTube series called "Drummond Ranch."
story: Ree Drummond, the "Pioneer Woman," is launching a new series — and this time, it doesn't center around cooking.

The Food Network star, 56, announced June 23 on Instagram that she and her husband, Ladd Drummond, have created a new internet series called "Drummond Ranch" that will follow the daily goings-on at the family's Oklahoma ranch.
She also included a full-length trailer for the series, which will air on a newly launched "Drummond Ranch" channel on YouTube.

"Have been working on this for awhile and am so excited to share this little sneak peek trailer with you. If you have missed the ranching/agricultural content on my show in recent years, you might enjoy our new Drummond Ranch series that’s starting soon," she wrote in her caption.
She continued, "I play only a supporting role in this show; the real stars are the cowboys (and cowgirls!), cattle, horses, weather, markets, ups, downs, and everything in between."
The new series will also feature her daughter Paige's May wedding to husband David Andersen as well as "the behind the scenes of setting it up on the ranch," she added.
The trailer kicks off with footage of Ladd Drummond tending to the ranch's horses and doing other chores in the early morning before sunrise.
"You're going to start at daylight and get as much done as you can as fast as you can throughout the day," he tells viewers.
Ree Drummond also appears cooking in her home kitchen as she jokes about her husband's tendency to “boss” her around.
Several of the couple's five kids — Alex, Paige, Bryce, Jamar, and youngest Todd —  are also seen doing various chores at the ranch.

Ree Drummond shared more details about the new series in a blog post on her official website, explaining that she and her husband hired a local camera crew who filmed the ranch's activities for several weeks.

"They covered so many different things, and we hope this series shows the hard work and business side of cattle ranching," she wrote of the crew, who, she added, would soon return to the ranch to continue filming.
"Anyone who watched the kids grow up on my cooking show will see that they’re officially all grown up and starting to come back and work more and more," she said of the couple's children.
The celebrity chef said viewers can expect the series to provide an authentic glimpse of what it looks like to operate a family ranch.

"You’ll see cowboys, weather, the dynamic between Ladd and his brother Tim," she wrote, "and you’ll hear about the different kinds of cattle operations, markets, and what it’s like in a family where all the kids are growing up and trying to figure out what role they will play in the ranch’s future."

title: Meet the Casa Amor Bombshells for ‘Love Island USA’ Season 7
summary: Meet the Casa Amor bombshells featured in "Love Island USA" Season 7, including Chris Seeley, Vanna Einerson and more.
story: The fourth week of “Love Island USA” kicked off one of the most exciting points of every season: Casa Amor. While the islanders have spent the previous weeks fostering current connections, Casa Amor presents an opportunity to test those loyalties. It’s a residence nearby where some of the islanders are sent to meet a group of new bombshells — all while those left at the villa are doing the same.

For this year’s Season 7, the seven girl islanders are sent to Casa, where they’re introduced to six guy bombshells. While the six boy islanders remain at the villa, five girl bombshells are added to stir things up.

Though Casa Amor week typically ends with the girl and guy islanders deciding between staying in their existing couples or coupling up with a bombshell, the show this year introduced new rules to Casa: All the islanders are starting Casa week single and will have to get into couples with new bombshells. At the end of the week, all the bombshells — the guys at Casa and the girls at the villa — will be sticking around, regardless of coupling status.
While viewers have gotten to know the existing “Love Island USA” Season 7 cast already, Episode 19 introduced all the new bombshells for Casa week. Here’s a look.
Meet “Love Island USA” Season 7 Casa Amor bombshells

Hometown: Richmond Hill, Ontario, Canada
Occupation: Tech consultant

title: Niecy Nash Roasts What Colman Domingo Wore as Her Wedding Officiant
summary: Niecy Nash jokes about Colman Domingo's yellow black outfit from when he officiated her August 2020 wedding to Jessica Betts.
story: Five years later, Niecy Nash still has thoughts on what Colman Domingo chose to wear to officiate her third wedding.

While reminiscing about her wedding to musician Jessica Betts on TODAY with Jenna & Friends on June 24, the actor told Jenna Bush Hager that "none other than the Colman Domingo" officiated the occasion.
But the Jenna & Friends guest co-host revealed what she "never forgave" Domingo, an Oscar-nominated actor, for doing the day of her wedding.
Nash is not a fan of the bright yellow and black ensemble "The Color Purple" star donned for the ceremony. The outfit is visible in the post Nash shared when she first announced the wedding.
"He just looked like a beautiful bumblebee," the comedian lovingly joked.
The August 2020 ceremony took place in Nash's backyard and had only 24 attendees, she told Jenna.
What did the "Claws" actress say when Domingo showed up to officiate the intimate occasion in a bright yellow suit?
“I said, 'You look like a fool. What do you have on? What are you wearing?'" Nash revealed.

Lately, the award show darling has been applauded for his red carpet looks. Domingo was also a co-chair of the 2025 Met Gala. Nash joked that she wishes the actor had his current eye for style when she said her vows.
“Now, he's a fashion guru," Nash laughed. "How come that didn’t happen before my wedding?”
A simpler choice would have been better for the big day, she said.
“You’re my officiant. You don’t got black slacks laying around?” she laughed.
The star's teasing, however, is all in good fun.
“But I love him. I love you Coleman,” Nash said, holding up her hands in the shape of a heart.
Nash’s relationship with Betts started as friendship but eventually blossomed into an unexpected romance, she recalled in a conversation on TODAY with Hoda & Jenna in 2021.

“If you are open to it, love can come from unexpected places,” Nash said during her previous TODAY appearance. “And I’ve never had a dear friend and then ended up dating them, so this is my first time.”
The couple married months after Nash divorced her second husband, Jay Tucker, in 2019.
“This is, by far, the greatest love of my life,” she said in 2021. “And part of that is because, for me, it’s the first time that I feel fully seen.”

title: 'Lizzie McGuire' Star Jake Thomas Reveals the Heartbreaking Way He Found Out Reboot Was Canceled
summary: Jack Thomas, who played Matt McGuire in Disney Channel's "Lizzie McGuire," revealed he found out the reboot was canceled through a friend and co-star Hilary Duff's social media post.
story: Disney+'s ill-fated "Lizzie McGuire" reboot remains a sore spot for many who rooted for the continuation of the early aughts series.
When Jake Thomas, the actor who played the mischievous younger brother to the show’s titular character, found out that the revival officially got canceled in 2020, he took it as a sign.

"I have a theory: to a certain degree, the show is cursed," the 35-year-old actor said during a June 14 interview on "Zach Sang Show Clips." During the episode, Thomas reflected on the series and its several brushes with revitalization.

For two seasons, Thomas appeared as Matt McGuire and appeared alongside Hilary Duff in the Disney Channel original series that aired from 2001 to 2004. The show inspired the 2003 film “The Lizzie McGuire Movie,” which had a theatrical release.

“Because this is not the first time we’ve tried to do a continuation of the show,” he explained. "Originally, we were going to do, after the original run on Disney Channel, they were going to put us on prime time ABC."
Thomas reflected on how Disney had once considered a spinoff series, which was going to follow Lizzie McGuire into high school.
"(It would have been) Lizzie McGuire: now she's in high school!" he explained. "But it was going to be a prime time, like a dramatic series ... it just never came together.”

Over a decade later, in 2019, Disney sought to revive its focus on Lizzie — this time, with the Disney+ reboot series that was meant to follow Lizzie as an adult. At the time, the studio announced the series on social media and later completed production on two episodes before its ultimate cancelation in 2020.
As the story goes, the reboot never saw the light of day. However, Thomas explained that he didn't hear about the series' cancelation from the studio or production, but through a friend.

“He’s like, 'Hey, man, I’m so sorry.' I was like, 'What? He was like, 'Hilary posted on Instagram,'" Thomas explained before detailing his experience of reading the post by Duff, in which she announced the reboot's cancelation and expressed her disappointment.
"I found out I wasn't going to have a job, which kind of sucked, and then later, I got a call," he recalled. "I mean, it sucked to find out I didn't have a job from Instagram."
“I’m definitely disheartened, just because, you know, I never thought they would really do a reboot,” he added. “When it did start to happen, it just it felt very unreal."
Thomas details the process being such a surreal experience, especially as the McGuire house had been brought back to life.

"I still to this day, it's kind of like, 'Did that really happen?'" he explained. "Because they recreated down to every detail they could find the McGuire house interior on the sound stage, and walking into that felt like that was a space that was so impactful within my life and my childhood, of growing up on that set and seeing it again, it was crazy.”
Thomas said the experience put him through "all the different stages of grief," but that he is now able to look back with perspective.
"It is what it is," he concluded. "My response nowadays is just like, 'That's Hollywood.'"

title: Niecy Nash-Betts Recalls Going From Ally to 'Card-Carrying Member' of the LGBTQ+ Community
summary: On TODAY, Niecy Nash-Betts recalled her love story with her wife, Jessica Betts, and said she's happy to be a "card-carrying member" of the LGBTQ+ community.
story: Niecy Nash-Betts is a proud "card-carrying member" of the LGBTQ+ community.
On the June 24 episode of TODAY with Jenna & Friends, Nash-Betts recalled her love story with her wife, Jessica Betts, and revealed how their relationship is different from her previous marriages.
Nash-Betts was previously married to Jay Tucker from 2011 to 2020. Before that, she was married to Don Nash, whom she divorced from in 2007.

"The first two times I was married, I was married to men and now I'm married to a woman. And I don't think it's about the gender that makes it special. It's just, I met my soulmate," she said while acting as a guest co-host on the show. "I wasn't living a sexually repressed life where I'm like, 'Oh my God, I really want to be married to a woman.' No, I just met the most beautiful soul."
"I never thought I would be a part of the community. I was adjacent. I was an ally, but now I'm a card-carrying member," she added.

Nash-Betts joked that she thought she was going to receive a "package," "manual" or nice housewarming gift from her friends when she became part of the LGBTQ+ community. However, she joked that her friends didn't get her anything at all.
"I got nothing, guys. Nothing!" she laughed.

Nash-Betts and Betts wed in 2020 in a beautiful backyard ceremony. She first revealed the wedding news in an Instagram post, with a photo of her and her wife walking down the aisle on their wedding day. In the snap, Colman Domingo, their wedding officiant, is seen standing and cheering them on.
"Mrs. Carol Denise Betts 💍 ," the "Reno 911!" star captioned the post.

title: From Chicken Wings to Ceramic Dolls, Mei Kawajiri Is Completely Transforming the Way We Think About Nail Art
summary: Mei Kawajiri's nail art has adorned the hands of celebrities like Gigi Hadid and FKA Twigs, stopping the show everywhere from award shows to high profile events like the Met Gala.
story: Mei Kawajiri's nail art has adorned the hands of celebrities like Gigi Hadid and FKA Twigs, stopping the show everywhere from award shows to high profile events like the Met Gala.

Known for painstaking detail, hand-painted illustrations and experimental 3D elements, Kawajiri's intricate designs bring a world of imagination to a deeply intimate artform. Kawaii, cats, breakfast pastries — a set from Nails by Mei not only reflects her talent and creativity, but also her interpretation of her clients' personalities.
But despite her designs frequently going viral (don't miss her chicken wing set), many followers are often left wondering: Who is the person behind these whimsical creations?

On the set of her photoshoot with TODAY.com, Kawajiri showed us firsthand the way she's constantly blurring the lines between manicurist and artist. For the nail artist, it's second nature; she's been at this since she was a teenager. Born in Kyoto, she started doing nails at 19 in Osaka and later honed her style working in Tokyo’s Harajuku, opening her own salon in 2006.
“My favorite nail -art style is 3D art, plus hand-painted detail plus some cute charm or everything together,” Kawajiri tells TODAY.

Experimenting with materials outside of regular polish and gels, Kawajiri has even used hair in her designs. One of her favorite creations, she says, was inspired by drawings her child made. She calls it one of her “dirty” nail sets — in direct opposition to the clean-girl soap nail trend.

“I think people love a ‘wow’ moment, something that they have never seen before. I don’t think they want to have it on themself, but they like to feel like [to see], ‘Oh, wow, this is something more fun than just beautiful nails,’” she says.
Eventually, Kawajiri made her way to New York in 2012, taking the advice of a friend who lived there who thought an American audience would appreciate her unique sets.

title: How Much Do the Dallas Cowboy Cheerleaders Make? Season 2 Sheds New Light
summary: Season 2 of “America’s Sweethearts: Dallas Cowboy Cheerleaders” sheds new light on how much the NFL pays the athletes.
story: When “America’s Sweethearts: Dallas Cowboy Cheerleaders” premiered in 2024, the docuseries left some viewers asking how much (or how little) the NFL cheerleaders are paid.
Season 2 of the popular Netflix series, which aired June 18, shows several members of the Dallas Cowboy Cheerleaders stepping up to push for more livable wages.

In light of the success of Season 1, some DCC members were emboldened to start a conversation with management about their pay, explaining their effort to make compensation better for future generations of cheerleaders.
Read on for what “America’s Sweethearts” reveals of how the DCC are paid.
What Season 1 Showed of DCC’s Salaries
Season 1 of “America’s Sweethearts” gave an inside look into what it takes to be an NFL cheerleader, from tryouts to playoffs.

The 36 women who end up on the team appear to spend hours at dance rehearsals, volunteering around Dallas, Texas, and performing at games. At one point in the docuseries, the cheerleaders’ coaching staff said that the dancers typically clock an 11-hour day on game days.

But the show also revealed that most of the women work an additional full-time job, on top of being a Cowboys cheerleader. In their introduction, some of the cheerleaders said they worked jobs as doctors, nurses, accountants, fitness instructors and more.
How Much Do NFL Cheerleaders Make?
In 2024, “America’s Sweethearts” director and executive producer Greg Whiteley told Glamour that he never received a “clean answer” on the cheerleaders’ wages.
“I think that’s because it varies depending on how senior you are in the group. You may even get paid more if you’re a group leader, though that was never clear to me,” he said.
The rates for NFL cheerleaders are not made public, but some reporting, as well as the docuseries, give insights into estimates.

In “America’s Sweethearts,” former Cowboys cheerleader Kat Puryear, who concluded her tenure on the team in 2022, compared their pay to that of “a substitute teacher” or a full-time “Chick-fil-A worker.”
In a follow-up video Puryear shared to TikTok in June 2024, she explained that, when she was on the team, the cheerleaders were paid a flat fee for games, in addition to an hourly rate.

For public appearances, cheerleaders were also paid an hourly rate and flat fee, but tenure played a role in that amount, she said in the video. Because many of the women work another job, Puryear said the public appearances were not required. She added that for practices, the athletes are solely compensated an hourly rate.
“So all in all, it’s a full-time commitment, part-time pay,” she said at the time.

As seen in the docuseries, DCC members also score several perks as part of their roles, including meal prep services, gym memberships, beauty services (tanning, nails, makeup, hair, skincare, etc.), products, dental treatments and more.

NBC Sports Boston reported in 2022 that NFL cheerleaders make, on average, about $150 per game. The athletes were reportedly also making about $50 to $75 for public appearances at the time, which altogether equated to about $22,500 per year.

However, pay differs among teams. The outlet reported that Dallas’ cheerleaders in 2022 were making about $15-20 per hour, which, with game and public appearance fees, totaled to about $75,000 a year.

Per old footage in the Netflix docuseries, the cheerleaders were, at one point, making $15 per game. However, in interviews with former cheerleaders, some said they were “surprised (the Cowboys) paid anything,” calling their job an “honorary position.”
Former cheerleader Tina Kalina, who was on the team in the 1980s, said in the docuseries that she made $35 per game.
“These millennials, X-Gen, whatever they’re called, they do look at it as a job, whereas us old-timers look at it as more of a privilege,” she said.
What Season 2 Reveals About DCC’s Salaries
In Season 2 of “America’s Sweethearts,” several members of the DCC have a message for Cowboys’ management: Put your money where your mouth is.
When it comes time to sign contracts for the year, a group consisting of several veteran DCC members unites to push for change.

While some DCC members are hesitant to confront management, saying they “can see both sides,” others opened up about financial difficulties like being unable to pay rent and “exhaustion” from working multiple jobs.

In the show, the group pushing for change consults with outside legal sources and meets with management, neither of which initially lead to changes. The team considers a walkout to protest the pay, which falls through. Many still debate not turning in their contracts unless changes are made.
In the season finale, however, the athletes receive great news: management has approved a 400% pay increase.
Before performing on TODAY June 23 with her fellow cheerleaders, DCC Jada Mclean, who helped lead the push for fair wages, reacted to the achievement.

“I’m super proud of all of us,” she said. “I think it was a moment of unity for our team. We all came together. I think we were very inspired by the women before us and we wanted to inspire the women who come after us.”
Mclean called the accomplishment “a big moment for women in sports,” adding that she hopes the raises make women feel “seen.”
DCC Reece Weaver echoed her teammate’s sentiment of unity, adding, “It’s just really empowering for a group of women to do this, but also, hopefully, inspiring other women to do as well.”
What has DCC said about pay?

In regards to the increased salaries revealed at the end of “America’s Sweethearts” Season 2, the Cowboys told NBC News in a statement June 18, “We’re pleased, as you’ll see in the series, that the Dallas Cowboys Cheerleaders were happy with the outcome.”
Charlotte Jones, Cowboys’ chief brand officer and daughter of team owner Jerry Jones, addressed the cheerleaders’ pay in Season 1 of the docuseries.

“There’s a lot of cynicism around pay for NFL cheerleaders — and as it should be. They’re not paid a lot,” Jones said in the first season. “But the facts are that they actually don’t come here for the money. They come here for something that’s actually bigger than that to them.”

“They have a passion for dance,” she continued. “There are not a lot of opportunities in the field of dance to get to perform at an elite level. It is about being a part of something bigger than themselves. It is about a sisterhood that they were able to form, about relationships that they have for the rest of their life.”

In 2018, former Cowboys cheerleader Erica Wilkins, who danced from 2014 to 2017, sued the organization for allegedly working over 40 hour weeks, making less than $7.25 per hour. The lawsuit, obtained by TODAY.com, also alleged that the team’s mascot made more than the cheerleaders.
At the time, Wilkins claimed in the lawsuit that she was making $200 per game. During her time on the team, Wilkins also claimed that her gross wages ranged from about $5,800 to $16,500 annually.
Per court documents, Wilkins filed to dismiss the case in July 2018. In 2019, Wilkins’ attorney told WFAA that the matter was resolved.
The Dallas Cowboys declined to comment at the time on cheerleader pay and Wilkins’ lawsuit.

The Cowboys aren’t the only team to face lawsuits from cheerleaders. In 2017, more than 20 organizations with cheerleading teams were named in an antitrust lawsuit filed by a Jane Doe representing cheerleaders across the NFL, NBC News reported. The suit alleged the NFL conspired to keep cheerleader wages as low as possible.
The NFL teams’ motion to dismiss the lawsuit was granted in May 2017, per court documents.

title: Jonathan Bailey Reacts to Sparking Online Chatter With Flip-Flops at Red Carpet
summary: Jonathan Bailey had fans divided over his outfit after wearing flip-flops in a recent red carpet appearance for "Jurassic World Rebirth."
story: Jonathan Bailey had fans divided over his outfit after wearing flip-flops in a recent red carpet appearance, but the "Jurassic World Rebirth" star has no regrets.
"I think what is cool is wearing stuff that you love," Bailey told Craig Melvin on TODAY June 24. "It gives you confidence. I think it’s a bangin’ look."
"Yes. I agree," his "Jurassic World" co-star Mahershala Ali said. "You can get away with it, brother."

Bailey showed off the look on June 16 at a London red carpet for the latest film in the "Jurassic World" franchise, which hits theaters on July 2. He wore black pants, a gray sweater, sunglasses and a pair of black flip-flops as he posed alongside Ali and fellow co-stars Scarlett Johansson and Rupert Friend.
The British actor joked on TODAY that his toes "wanted to come to the party."
Fans were divided in their reaction after the "Jurassic World" Instagram account shared a photo of Bailey's red carpet look.
"Jonathan Bailey and those damn flip flops," one fan commented with a crying emoji.
"Flip flops? How tacky!!" another wrote.
"Johnny and the flip flops. I’m here for it!" another fan commented.
"Jbailey wearing flip flops is the charm lol," an approving fan wrote.

Fans have also become enamored with the small glasses that Bailey wears in the movie as paleontologist Dr. Henry Loomis. He said on TODAY that he wore glasses for 10 years made by the company Cubitts, which created the ones he wore in "Jurassic World Rebirth."
The spectacles are also an homage to another famous character in a summer blockbuster.
"It's obviously a nod to (Richard) Dreyfuss in 'Jaws,'" Bailey said about the iconic movie, which is celebrating its 50th anniversary this year.

title: Jenna Bush Hager Calls Her July Book Club Pick a 'Delicious' Summer Thriller
summary: Jenna Bush Hager's July 2025 book club pick is "Happy Wife" by Meredith Lavender and Kendall Shores. She calls it a "delicious" thriller.
story: A prominent lawyer goes missing on the night of his birthday party in Florida, rocking the small community of Winter Park — and the townspeople are quick to suggest his younger wife is capable of murder, in Jenna Bush Hager's latest book club pick.
“Happy Wife” by Meredith Lavender and Kendall Shores, publishing on June 24, is the July Read With Jenna pick, which Jenna calls a “delicious” summer read.
“‘Happy Wife’ is one of those delicious, fun summer books that you’ll open on the beach and never put down,” Jenna says.
"Happy Wife" by Meredith Lavender and Kendall Shores

Nora Davies, a 28-year-old swim instructor, is barely making ends meet when she connects with Will Somerset, a 46-year-old divorced father. Their whirlwind romance turns into a swift marriage, creating endless gossip for the people of Winter Park.
When Nora wakes up the day after Will's birthday party without her husband by her side, the community focuses on her as the reason for his disappearance.

“The setting in a community outside of Orlando, with tons of secrets, is so much fun for the summer, and I found the women of this novel to be complex and interesting, while it being the type of mystery you can’t wait to finish,” Jenna says.

Lavender, a TV writer and producer, and Shores, who works in communications, tell TODAY.com they landed on the idea for what would become “Happy Wife” after what they describe as a "meet-cute" at their children’s school.

“In classic Atlanta fashion, we couldn’t find a parking space, so my husband, my daughter and I blow in probably 10 minutes late,” Shores says. “I don’t think Meredith’s ever been 10 minutes late to anything in her life. She’s there, her son is seated, my daughter sits down next to him, I’m sweating.”
The kids had been tasked with completing a scavenger hunt while waiting for everyone to arrive, and Shores says she started panicking thinking her child wouldn’t have enough time to find things.

“Then Meredith’s son looks over at my daughter and says, ‘You can copy off of me,’ and Meredith and I just had a mom moment where we were like, ‘Aww!’ and we struck up a friendship through birthday parties and other things.”
It was at a book fair where Shores mustered up the strength to ask Lavender about her career in writing and producing for TV, and a few months later, she approached her with an idea for a book.

“I had an idea in mind, sort of loosely inspired by the way that we, at the time, were all obsessed with the Murdaugh murders,” Shores says. “And you could see the way that, in a small town in South Carolina, the way that lore and history and lineage in that community shapes a crime.”
“For me, growing up in Winter Park, which has its own lore and its own kind of energy, I just couldn’t stop picturing what would it would be like if that happened in Winter Park,” she adds.
Lavender says that after Shores pitched her the idea, her brain went into “hyperdrive.”

“I think it was just lightning in a bottle, you know? It’s that moment in time where, like, right idea, right person and then right moment,” Lavender says. “So I think for us, it was a really fun process.”

“We’d crack each other up. We’d text each other, she would send me, like, a copy of the chapter, and I would be reading, texting her, like, ‘Ha ha, this line!’ or, like, screengrabs of it,” she continues. “And I think we both did that for each other all the way through.”

The pair wrote the book together over the course of a few months. Shores summarizes the book: “A young woman falls in love with a man who is older than her and his friends don’t approve of the courtship or the marriage, so she throws a party in the hopes of winning them over, and the morning after the party, he’s missing.”
“This book, too, is about choice. These are people who just keep choosing their choice, doing it. I think that’s the fascinating thing,” Shores adds.

The authors hint at what may be coming after the release, including a possible TV adaptation ("For me, obviously, it's a no-brainer," Lavender says) and potentially more books, including with characters from the Winter Park universe.
Recalling when they found out Jenna had chosen their book, Shores and Lavender say there was a lot of squealing.

“To have the opportunity to even have a book on a shelf somewhere, like, I’ll be able to take my daughter to a bookstore and point at something and say, ‘We made this. It’s possible to make whatever you want,’” Shores says. “And so for Jenna to see it and like it and to give it this extra platform is like, ‘What?’”
Lavender adds, “When you respect somebody and their body of work and the thing that they do, and then they respect your work back, it’s overwhelming.”
“She’s done so many cool things in her career, and then the fact that, you know, her love of books is now creating the space for people to get a spotlight — it’s so cool,” Lavender says.

title: Tallulah Willis Responds to Comment She Shouldn’t ‘Expose’ Dad Bruce Willis With Photos
summary: Tallulah Willis replied to a fan who criticized her for posting photos of her father, Bruce Willis, saying it was a violation of privacy.
story: Tallulah Willis’ recent Instagram post featuring new pictures of father Bruce Willis led to some critical comments, including one she replied to.
The actor’s youngest daughter with ex-wife Demi Moore is responding to a bit of backlash she received for sharing photos of her with her dad on Instagram on June 22.

Some fans took issue with the younger Willis’ decision to post the shots of her father, who has been diagnosed with frontotemporal dementia. One person disapproved of the 31-year-old posting the photos for privacy reasons, prompting her to reply.
“I don’t think you should expose your dad to the public! He is vulnerable! And some things should be kept private! You don’t have his permission to post it!” the person wrote in the comments.

“Hi. I hear that. As a family we use our discretion when posting,” Tallulah Willis responded. “Today was a great day filled with smiles. I made the judgement call to show that to the world, because I know what he means to everyone.”

The post featured one image of the “Die Hard” star, who turned 70 in March, smiling at his daughter, as well as one of them hugging each other and another of him with Tallulah Willis’ fiancé, Justin Acee.
“Sunday funday at Grams ! Grateful 🕊️,” Tallulah Wills captioned the post, alluding to spending time at her grandmother's home.
While some people took issue with her decision to show Willis, many supported it.
“Thank you for sharing your dad with us, these precious moments are so beautiful ❤️,” one person wrote.

“As a caregiver for my mom, who battled Alzheimer’s for over 10 years, your posts are a beautiful way of showing the joy in the small moments,” someone else explained. “Having a network of families who share this experience, and who are NOT judgmental, is everything. Those making negative comments hopefully will never have to go through this. I wish you all the best. ❤️”

“I love and appreciate your photos of your dad. All I see is absolute love and support and smiling faces,” another person commented. “I truly think these photos are a lovely gift to your family and to the world. The comments by clueless individuals make me think they wouldn’t have the compassion you have as a family. I feel as though they may lock their family member away out of shame and embarrassment, which I find cruel. So much love sent to you and your sweet family. ❤️‍🔥”
“This is a loving picture. There should be no criticism of her posting this picture. Bruce and his daughter are raising awareness, so this can be cured someday,” another fan wrote.
“Thanks for sharing Bruce with us. It’s good to see his smile and yours as well,” commented one other person.
Tallulah Willis has previously spoken about the challenges her dad’s condition presents, noting she and her family wanted to make it something positive.

“The bigger version of what I’m trying to do (is) if we can take something that we’re struggling with as a family and individually and help other people to turn it around, to make something beautiful about it, that’s really special for us,” she said on “The Drew Barrymore Show” in 2023.
Last year, Tallulah Wills appeared on TODAY and gave an update on her father, noting the closeness in the family.
“He’s doing stable, which in this situation is good, and is hard,” she said. “There’s painful days, but there’s so much love.”

title: ‘Love Island USA’ Just Put a Twist on Casa Amor: Here Are the New Rules
summary: In Episode 19 of “Love Island USA” Season 7, the girl islanders head to Casa Amor to kick off what viewers know as one of the most exciting points in the show.
story: In Episode 19 of “Love Island USA” Season 7, the girl islanders  head to Casa Amor to kick off what viewers know as one of the most exciting points in the show. But all that doesn’t happen without a twist.

When the islanders receive a text that they are about to play a kissing game, the boys suit up — with blindfolds and noise-canceling headphones — as the girls take seats to await directions.
